Freshwater systems like rivers and lakes support biodiversity in several ways, including providing habitats for a wide variety of aquatic organisms, such as fish, amphibians, mollusks, and aquatic plants. These organisms depend on the quality and quantity of water, as well as the physical features of the ecosystem, like the presence of rocks, gravel, and vegetation, in order to thrive.

In addition to supporting biodiversity, freshwater systems provide essential services such as drinking water and irrigation. Water from these systems is essential for human, animal, and plant survival, and is used for drinking, cooking, and cleaning. It is also used for irrigation to grow crops, which is essential for local and global food supplies.

However, these essential services are threatened by various human activities like pollution, overextraction, and destruction of freshwater habitats. When water becomes polluted, it can harm aquatic species and create health hazards for humans who consume the water. Overextraction can result in the depletion of groundwater, leading to reductions in stream flows and water availability. Destruction of freshwater habitats can lead to fragmentation and loss of biodiversity, leading to long-term negative impacts on the functioning of the entire ecosystem.

To ensure the sustainability of freshwater systems, it is critical to develop and implement comprehensive management plans that help reduce human pressures and prevent negative impacts on freshwater biodiversity and essential services. These plans must take into account the diverse needs of different stakeholders while also prioritizing the conservation and preservation of freshwater ecosystems for future generations.
